learningAssessment.title: Quiz 2

lcMultipleSelect.lcQuestion: For the following conref referencing element sample, select all the answers that are true.

lcAnswerOption.lcAnswerContent: The <step> element is missing required content.
The <cmd> element is missing required content.
The <cmd> element is not required here because the <step> element is a referencing element and its contents will be replaced when the conref is resolved.
The <cmd> element is required here even though the <step> element is a referencing element.

lcMultipleSelect.lcFeedbackIncorrect: The content must be valid both before and after the conref is resolved. Since the <step> element requires the <cmd> element, the <cmd> element is required even though it will be repaced when the conref is resolved. The <cmd> element does not require any content. So, this example has all of the required structure to be valid before the conref is resolved.
lcMultipleSelect.lcFeedbackCorrect: Correct. Even though the <step> element is a referencing element it must be valid before the conref is resolved.

lcTrueFalse.lcQuestion: A conref will always resolve correctly when published even if the topic that contains the referenced element is not in the published map nor any of its submaps.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackIncorrect: Sorry. If your content is in a content management system, it might appear that any conref will resolve correctly regardless of whether the referenced element and the referencing element are reachable through the same map. But, your publishing configuration might require that the topic containing a referenced element for a conref be referenced in the published map or one of its submaps. The best practice is to reference all of the required content in the published map.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackCorrect: Right. All referenced elements must be reachable through the main published map. That would include one of its submaps if it has them. Your publishing configuration might not require all referenced topics to be referenced directly in a map, but this is still the best practice.

lcSingleSelect.lcQuestion: If you need to include a topic in a map for reuse purposes only, how should you do it? Choose the best answer.

lcAnswerOption.lcAnswerContent: Use a topicref to include the topic in a submap with the toc attribute set to “no” on the topicref to the submap.
Use a topicref to include the topic in the map, and set the proceesing-role attribute of the topicref to “no”.
Use a topicref to include the topic in the map, and set the toc, linking, and search attributes of the topicref to “no”.

lcSingleSelect.lcFeedbackIncorrect: Setting three attributes - toc, linking, and search - to “no” has the same effect as setting the processing-role attribute to “no”, but setting just one attribute is a simpler solution.
lcSingleSelect.lcFeedbackCorrect: This is the best answer. Setting the toc, linking, and search attributes to “no” has the same effect.
